entry.title: Re: Not able to find /LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE package
entry.content:
This is a very common issue for learners using the SAP BTP ABAP Trial or a personal system instead of the official SAP Learning System Access (LSA).

The package /LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE (and the table /LRN/S4D400_APT inside it) does not exist on the standard public SAP BTP Trial. It is exclusive to the paid/official training systems provided by SAP Learning System Access.

Since you are likely on the free BTP Trial, you cannot "add" this package. Instead, you must manually create your own objects that mimic the missing ones.

The exercise asks you to copy /LRN/S4D400_APT. This is just a simple Flight table. On the BTP Trial, you have an almost identical table available: /DMO/FLIGHT.

entry.title: KPI Tags in SAP Fiori Elements List Report (OData V4) — Beyond Analytical Applications
entry.content:
Introduction

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) tags are commonly associated with analytical applications in SAP Fiori, but did you know you can also implement them in standard non-analytical list report pages?

OData V4 in SAP Fiori elements provides a manifest-based configuration approach that lets you add dynamic, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page—without needing an analytical service.

This blog walks you through the official implementation approach to show how to:

  • Configure KPI tags in manifest.json
  • Create reusable KPI fragments with the macros:KPITag building block
  • Bind dynamic data and handle press events
  • Understand the architecture and design patterns

Why KPI Tags Matter in List Reports

A KPI tag is a compact, clickable indicator that displays:

  • A numerical value (e.g., total cost, contribution amount, order count)
  • A unit or measurement (currency, percentage, days)
  • A visual status (color-coded: Success, Warning, Error, Information)
  • Optional icon and tooltip

In list reports, KPI tags provide at-a-glance insights without cluttering the data table. They're especially valuable for:

  • HR & Benefits applications — Show headcount, enrollment rates, total costs
  • Sales dashboards — Display order counts, revenue, pipeline value
  • Finance reports — Highlight outstanding invoices, approvals pending
  • Operations — Monitor KPIs like availability, efficiency, cycle time

Part 1: Understanding the Two Approaches

Approach 1: Analytical Applications (Analytical List Pages)

  • Requires an analytical data source with aggregated/pre-calculated data
  • Configured via CDS annotations in the backend as well as manifest configuration in UI
  • Example: SAP Analytical List Pages (ALP)
  • Best for: Large-scale data analysis, multi-dimensional analytics, pre-aggregated metrics

Approach 2: OData V4 List Reports (What This Blog Covers)

  • Uses manifest-based configuration + custom XML fragments
  • Works with any non-analytical OData V4 service
  • Configuration entirely in the frontend (manifest.json + UI5 fragments)
  • Fully customizable via UI5 controller extensions
  • Best for: Standard enterprise list reports, responsive dashboards, interactive KPIs

This approach is ideal for developers who want simplicity and flexibility without backend annotation complexity.

Part 2: Setting Up KPI Tags in manifest.json

KPI tags are registered in the manifest under the keyPerformanceIndicators section within the list report target:

"targets": {
  "mainPage": {
    "type": "Component",
    "id": "Default",
    "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
    "options": {
      "settings": {
        "contextPath": "/RootEntity",
        "variantManagement": "None",
        "initialLoad": true,
        "keyPerformanceIndicators": {
          "myKPITag": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITag"
          },
          "myKPIWithPress": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITagWithPress"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Key Points:

  • keyPerformanceIndicators — Container for all KPI definitions in this page

  • myKPITag, myKPIWithPress — Unique identifiers for each KPI block (you can name these anything)

  • template — Path to the fragment file (can be in your app namespace or SAP's example path)

You can define multiple KPI blocks by adding more entries. Each entry corresponds to one fragment template.

Part 3: Building KPI Fragments with the macros:KPITag Building Block

SAP recommends using the KPI building block (macros:KPITag) to maintain consistent design with analytical applications.

Simple KPI Fragment (Static Values)

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  
  <macros:KPITag
    number="0"
    unit="Days"
    status="Error"
    showIcon="true"
    press=".extension.sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.LRExtend.onKPIPressed"
  />
  
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Properties Reference

Property

Type

Purpose

Example

number

Number

The KPI value to display

0, 5000, 15.5

unit

String

Unit or measurement label

"Days", "USD", "%"

status

String

Visual indicator color

"Success", "Warning", "Error", "Information"

showIcon

Boolean

Display status icon

true / false

press

String

Event handler for click

.extension.[controller.path].onKPIPressed

tooltip

String

Hover text

"Total Orders"

visible

Boolean

Conditional visibility

true / false

enabled

Boolean

Enable/disable interaction

true / false

Part 4: Handling KPI Press Events

When a KPI tag is clicked, the press handler in your controller extension is triggered:

Step 1: Define the Controller Extension

In your manifest, register a controller extension for the ListReport:

"sap.ui5": {
  "extends": {
    "extensions": {
      "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
        "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
          "controllerName": "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 2: Implement the Press Handler

In your ListReportExt.controller.js:

sap.ui.define(
  ["sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension"],
  function(ControllerExtension) {
    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
      {
        onKPIPressed: function(oEvent) {
          const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
          const sKPIId = oSource.getId();
          
          sap.m.MessageToast.show("KPI " + sKPIId + " was pressed!");
          
          // Add custom logic here:
          // - Filter the table
          // - Navigate to detail page
          // - Show breakdown analysis
          // - Trigger backend action
        }
      }
    );
  }
);

Step 3: Register in Fragment

Reference the handler in your fragment's press event:

<macros:KPITag
  number="0"
  unit="Days"
  status="Error"
  press=".extension.your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onKPIPressed"
/>

Part 5: Building Multi-KPI Layouts with FlexBox

For a professional dashboard with multiple KPIs, use FlexBox for responsive layout:

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  <FlexBox 
    direction="Row"
    wrap="Wrap"
    gap="2rem"
    justifyContent="SpaceAround"
    alignItems="Start">
    
    <!-- KPI 1 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Total Orders" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="1234"
        unit="Orders"
        status="Success"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 2 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Revenue" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="523000"
        unit="USD"
        status="Information"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 3 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Pending Approvals" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="47"
        unit="Items"
        status="Warning"
      />
    </VBox>
  </FlexBox>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Part 6: Binding Data Models

To make KPIs dynamic (not just static values), you need to bind them to data models.

Creating a KPI Data Model

In your ListReportExt controller:

onInit: function() {
  const oKPIModel = new sap.ui.model.json.JSONModel({
    totalOrders: 1234,
    revenue: 523000,
    pendingApprovals: 47,
    costStatus: "Success"
  });
  
  this.getView().setModel(oKPIModel, "kpiModel");
}

Binding in Fragment

<macros:KPITag
  number="{kpiModel>/totalOrders}"
  unit="Orders"
  status="{kpiModel>/costStatus}"
/>

Updating Data Dynamically

fetchKPIData: function() {
  const oModel = this.getView().getModel(); // OData model
  
  oModel.read("/RootEntity", {
    success: (oData) => {
      const oKPIModel = this.getView().getModel("kpiModel");
      oKPIModel.setData({
        totalOrders: oData.OrderCount,
        revenue: oData.TotalRevenue,
        pendingApprovals: oData.ApprovalCount
      });
    }
  });
}

Part 7: Best Practices and Design Patterns

1. Responsive Design

  • Use wrap="Wrap" in FlexBox for mobile compatibility
  • Test on different screen sizes
  • Consider hiding KPIs on very small screens if needed

2. Status Color Coding

Use status colors to convey meaning:

  • Success (Green) — All good, target met
  • Warning (Orange) — Attention needed, approaching limit
  • Error (Red) — Critical, action required
  • Information (Blue) — Neutral, FYI

3. Meaningful Units

  • Always include a unit if applicable (currency, count, percentage, time)

4. Interactive Press Handlers

Make KPIs actionable:

  • Filter the list to show related records

  • Open a breakdown popover with summary data

5. Loading States

Use busy indicators while fetching data:

<FlexBox busy="{kpiModel>/loading}">
  <macros:KPITag number="{kpiModel>/value}" />
</FlexBox>

Part 8: Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue

Solution

KPI tags not showing

Verify manifest template path is correct; ensure fragment file exists at that location

Static values work, but binding doesn't

Check model name matches in binding (e.g., {kpiModel>/...}); verify model is set before fragment renders

Press event not firing

Ensure press handler includes .extension. prefix; verify controller extension is registered in manifest

Mobile layout broken

Add wrap="Wrap" to FlexBox; test responsive breakpoints; use sap.ui.Device for responsive logic

Blank KPI in production

Check backend OData service returns required fields; add error handling for failed reads

Part 9: Comparison — Analytical List Pages vs. OData V4 Manifest-Based KPIs

Configuration

CDS annotations + Manifest Configuration

Manifest Configuration only

Data Source

Analytical data models with aggregation

Any OData V4 service

Setup Complexity

High (requires analytical CDS views)

Low (JSON config + fragment)

Customization

Framework-driven

Full UI5 flexibility

Performance

Optimized for large aggregations

Good for summary metrics

Event Handling

Predefined navigation & analytics

Custom controller logic

Best For

Enterprise analytics dashboards

Standard business apps with KPI summaries

Learning Curve

Steep (analytics concepts)

Gentle (standard UI5 patterns)

Part 10: Live Example Reference

SAP provides a working example in the Flexible Programming Model Explorer:

Custom KPI Tags in List Report — FPM Explorer

This interactive demo shows:

  • Static KPI tags

  • KPI tags with press events

  • Various status types and layouts
  • Responsive behavior

Recommended: Clone this example and adapt it to your use case.

Part 11: What's Next? — Custom Charts & KPI Visualization

Coming in Next Blog:

In this blog, we learned how to add interactive KPI tags to any list report page. But what happens when users click on a KPI?

In the next blog, we'll explore:

  1. Building Custom Charts — Visualize KPI data using chart libraries
  2. Mapping KPI Data to Chart Models — Prepare and transform data from your OData service
  3. Opening Charts in Dialogs/Popovers — Display detailed analysis when KPI is clicked
  4. Multi-dimensional Visualizations — Show data breakdowns by different dimensions
  5. Dynamic Chart Updates — Refresh visualizations based on filter selections

Imagine clicking on a "Revenue" KPI and instantly seeing a pie chart breakdown by product category, or a bar chart comparing revenue across regions. That's what we'll build next!

Resources

  • SAP Fiori Elements Documentation — Creating Key Performance Indicators
  • macros:KPITag API Reference
  • FPM Explorer — Custom KPI Tags Example
  • SAP Community — Fiori Elements
  • Analytical List Page Documentation

Summary

KPI tags are not limited to analytical applications. By leveraging OData V4's manifest-based configuration and SAP UI5's flexible architecture, you can add powerful, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page.

Key Takeaways:

  • KPI tags work with standard (non-analytical) OData V4 services

  • Configuration is simple: manifest entry + fragment + optional controller logic

  • Full customization via UI5 — binding, styling, event handling

  • Responsive design built-in via FlexBox

  • Press handlers enable analysis and interaction

Whether you're building HR dashboards, sales pipelines, financial reports, or operational monitors, KPI tags can elevate user experience by providing instant insights at a glance.

Start experimenting with the FPM Explorer example today, and stay tuned for our next blog on custom charts and KPI visualization!

Questions or feedback? Drop a comment below—I'd love to hear about your KPI use cases!

entry.title: Re: SAP BP best practice: payer vs bill to when member VA...
entry.content:
Hey,

 

 

1. Core Principle (Most Important)

In SAP SD/FI, VAT liability and invoice legality must follow the VAT-liable legal entity, not the entity that pays.

Whoever’s VAT number must appear on the invoice should normally be the payer for tax determination purposes.

The paying agent is economically settling the invoice, but is not VAT-liable.

This drives almost all configuration decisions.

2. Recommended BP Role Model (High Level)

- Member = Payer (VAT-liable party)

- Paying Agent = Bill-to / Alternative Payer

Not the other way around.

Why:

  • VAT determination in SD is driven by payer at sales-org level (as you stated)

  • Invoice must legally belong to the member

  • Credit notes must legally be raised to the member

  • VAT reporting must reference the member

The paying agent is acting on behalf of the member, not replacing them as VAT debtor.

3. BP Role Assignment (Concrete)

Member (VAT-liable)

BP Role Purpose
Sold-to (SP)Contractual member
Payer (PY)VAT determination & legal invoice party
Bill-to (optional)If invoice header needs member name
FI CustomerReceives invoice & credit memo

Key settings

  • Member’s VAT registration number maintained in:

    • BP → Tax Numbers

    • Assigned to correct country & tax category

  • This VAT number will:

    • Drive VAT determination

    • Print on invoice

    • Appear on credit notes

Paying Agent

BP Role Purpose
Bill-to (BP)Invoice recipient (C/O)
Alternative PayerCash settlement
FI CustomerPayment handling

Key settings

  • Paying agent does NOT drive VAT

  • VAT number can exist for information, but:

    • Must NOT be used for tax determination

  • Address can be printed as C/O line

4. Invoice Layout (C/O Requirement)

This is a form issue, not a master-data misuse issue.

Correct approach

  • Invoice header:

    • Legal party: Member

    • VAT number: Member

  • Address block:

    • “C/O Paying Agent”

  • SAP forms (Adobe / SmartForms):

    • Use Bill-to address

    • Prefix with “C/O”

    • Reference Sold-to / Payer for VAT & legal text

This avoids distorting the BP model just to satisfy formatting.

5. VAT Number Maintenance (Critical)

Best Practice

Entity VAT Number Usage
MemberMandatoryTax determination + invoice
Paying AgentOptionalInformational only

Do NOT

  • Put paying agent VAT number on payer role

  • Override tax country to force tax logic

If VAT is driven by payer + sales org, the payer must be the member.

6. Credit Notes & Payment to Another BP

This is standard SAP functionality.

Credit Note Issued To Member

  • Credit memo posted to:

    • Member AR account

  • VAT reversed correctly (member VAT number)

Payment Made to Paying Agent

Use Alternative Payee functionality.

Option A – Alternative Payee (Recommended)

In BP → FI Customer → Payment Transactions:

  • Assign Alternative Payee = Paying Agent

  • Enable:

    • “Alternative payee allowed”

  • Result:

    • Credit memo stays on member AR

    • Payment is made to paying agent’s bank

This is fully standard SAP FI.

Option B – One-Time or Clearing Account (Not Recommended)

Sometimes used, but:

  • Breaks audit trail

  • Complicates AR reconciliation

  • Avoid unless regulatory reasons

7. Bank Master Data (Best Practice)

Paying Agent

  • Maintain bank account(s) here

  • Used for:

    • Incoming payments

    • Outgoing credit note payments

Member

  • No bank account required if they never receive cash directly

Payment flow

Credit Memo → Member AR Payment Run → Paying Agent bank account

Linked via Alternative Payee.

8. Standard SAP Patterns You Can Reference

SAP Concepts Used

  • Business Partner roles (SP / BP / PY)

  • VAT determination via payer

  • Alternative Payee (FI-AR)

  • C/O addressing via invoice form

  • Credit memo posting to original payer

SAP Notes / Keywords to Search

(Exact note numbers vary by release)

  • “Alternative Payee in Accounts Receivable”

  • “VAT determination payer sales organization”

  • “SD invoice C/O address”

  • “Agent payer scenario SAP SD FI”

9. Summary Recommendation

Topic Recommendation
PayerMember
VAT numberMember only for tax
Paying agent roleBill-to + Alternative Payee
Invoice layoutMember legal entity, Paying Agent as C/O
Credit notesPosted to Member
PaymentTo Paying Agent bank via Alternative Payee
CustomizationMinimal – mostly standard

 

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: RANDOM FOREST ITERATION 1
entry.content:
DATA COLLECTION AND PREPARATION

  1. First, we collected approximately 12 years of available daily stock data, for a total of 3,091 observations:
  2. Then we created additional measurements “gauges” such as RSI and MACD.
    • Relative Strength Index (RSI from 0 to 100) measures strength and speed for stock price changes.  Interpretation: RSI above 70 is commonly interpreted as overbought and historically associated with increased risk of pullbacks (leading to lower stock price).
    • Moving Average Convergence / Divergence (MACD) captures changes in momentum by comparing short- and long-term exponential moving averages.
  3. Next step included running a few raw data plots to visually check the data.  Of course, we first split the stock prices data set 80/20 into training (blue line) and testing (red line). The numbers are in Vietnamese dong. ($1 USD ~ 26,300 VND).  Obviously, the data is split chronologically, so that 80% training set is the oldest data and 20% validation is the newest.

RStudio is the statistical platform to perform these analyses and random forest predictions.

Daily returns (stock price on day 2 / stock price on day 1) are not quite normally distributed so we take a note of this for subsequent improvements (iteration 2):

 

TREE SELECTION AND PRUNING

Although the random forest model used in this analysis is globally nonlinear, at any given day the next-day price can be viewed as a function of several state variables—recent prices, momentum, volatility, and volume—corresponding to a point on a high-dimensional response surface. Over a sufficiently small neighborhood around the current market state, this surface can be locally approximated by a linear function. In this sense, even a complex nonlinear model behaves approximately linearly in the immediate vicinity of the observations on which it is trained.

This local approximation helps explain why short-horizon predictability may exist despite the absence of reliable long-term forecasting power. Small changes in inputs lead to proportionally small changes in the predicted price, allowing the model to exploit local structure without committing to a global trend. As the market state evolves and moves away from this neighborhood, however, the approximation deteriorates quickly, naturally limiting the persistence of predictability and helping to explain why even modest transaction costs can overwhelm the signal.

Formally, the next-day price can be represented as a multivariable function

where the inputs ​ represent features such as lagged prices, average trend, volatility.

Algorithmic Perspective: RMSE Minimization and Ensemble Averaging

From an algorithmic standpoint, this behavior arises not from explicit linearization, but from the way random forests are constructed.  Each decision tree is built through a greedy, recursive procedure that selects split points to locally minimize the root of the mean squared error (RMSE) of the next-day price prediction.  At each node, the algorithm chooses the variable and threshold that most reduces in-sample error, without considering the global structure of the tree or future splits.  This process produces a piecewise-constant approximation that is locally optimized for short-horizon accuracy.  The random forest then averages predictions across many such trees, each trained on a bootstrap sample and a random subset of predictors, which reduces variance and stabilizes forecasts.  As a result, the model captures local regularities in the data while remaining inherently sensitive to changes in market conditions, reinforcing the short-lived nature of the observed predictability.

Formally, at each node of a given tree, the algorithm selects a split (j, s) — variable x and threshold s — that minimizes the in-sample squared error within that node.  Let I denote the set of observations reaching the node.  The optimal split solves

where IL and IR are the left and right child nodes induced by the split.  Y bars are the mean next-day prices within each child.  This greedy optimization is repeated recursively until stopping criteria — such as minimum node size or maximum depth — are reached.

Because each tree is trained on a bootstrap sample of the data, approximately one-third of observations are excluded from the construction of any given tree.  These unused observations provide a natural out-of-sample testing set for that tree, forming the basis of the out-of-bag (OOB) error used to assess predictive performance.

Next came the testing of the OOB and tree pruning.

Without full statistical rigor of rules such as 1-SE, just visually it appears that 100 trees is enough to bring the error (Mean Square Error) down to almost its minimum. We can formally compare various error levels by the number of trees to make the pruning decision:

  Trees Train_RMSE Test_RMSE

1     5    1182.18   2397.00

2    20    1080.01   2244.43

3    50    1067.00   2222.47

4   100    1036.87   2207.22

5   200    1058.35   2183.04

One can see that the rate of MSE decrease drops, or slows down, between 100 and 200 trees. Based on this information, our heuristic cutoff is established at 100 trees.

PREDICTION: RMSE

 

The predicted distribution tells the following story:

  • Extreme ends move further away from the ideal line (red dotted line).
  • Vertical dotted lines between the predicted values (stock prices) and the red dotted line, if squared and summed, comprise the MSE.
  • Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) is 2188 (in Vietnamese dongs) which translates into less than 3% of the stock price level.  

So, we can proceed to plotting the predictions against the historical data.

The blue line represents historical stock prices (80% oldest), the red line is also historical stock prices, but newest (our model’s testing data) and green dots are the stock price predictions. First plot shows the entire data and second one zooms in on the testing data mostly:

Visually, the green dots (predictions) track the red line (actual stock prices) closely. There are some notable deviations though, but in general for the two-year period our basic random forest model performs reasonably well.

 

BASIC RANDOM FOREST REFINEMENT

Given the noticeable deviations of predictions from the actual stock prices, we introduce more predictors:

  1. Lag_1: one day prior share price. While this limits the predictive interval to only one day, this addition, as we see later, improves the predictive power.
  2. SMA_5 which is simple 5-day moving average =  

 

 

  1. EMA_12 which is 12-day exponential moving average, i.e. moving average where we assign higher weight to the most recent stock price

where a=2 / (N+1)

 

  1. We construct an average intraday price proxy for smoothing purposes as follows:  avg_daily=(open+low+high)/3. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The model essentially asks, “Given the prior day’s stock price and the short-term trend & momentum today, what price do we expect tomorrow?”

  • Lag-1 → inertia / memory
  • SMA & EMA → short-term trend
  • RSI → overbought / oversold pressure
  • MACD → momentum turning points

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Addition of these incremental variables brings the RMSE significantly down: from 2188 (below 3% of the stock price) to 809 which is below 1% of the stock price.

In plain English: this random forest regression predicts stock prices fairly closely to their actual levels at short horizons. 

 

RANDOM FOREST: TRUE PREDICTIONS

The logic of the random forest model has been clear: train the model on the 80% of historical data then make predictions for the 20% of the newest historical data, i.e., test the model on the unseen data. From this point, we went further – predicting Masan Group’s stock prices for a few days in a row.  Specifically

  • Original model’s last day of known stock price was Friday December 12, 2025. How does the model perform on the following Monday when the markets open?  I.e., what stock price does it predict for Monday December 15, 2025?
  • For Tuesday December 16, 2025, stock prediction, I add the prices from Monday and re-run the model to predict December 16 price. I repeated this process for two weeks through December 26 especially noting the period of “Santa rally” as during this period the deviations may be interesting.

Rather than holding the model fixed, we re-train the random forest each day as new observations become available. This expanding-window approach allows the model to adapt to evolving market conditions and prevents mechanical error accumulation.  This differs from recursive multi-step forecasting with a fixed model, where forecast errors compound over time.

Here are the results:

While each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day prediction path should be interpreted as a conditional scenario generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than as a set of independent forecasts from a fixed model.  Predictions generated this way paint an interesting picture:

  • Typical prediction error or edge: ~0.5%–1.5%
  • Often much smaller day-to-day moves
  • Pragmatically, any usable signal is small relative to the price level, consistent with liquid asset classes
  • This may be important if the round-trip costs run up to 0.10% (5 bps for entry and exit trades respectively)

Here is the plot of these predictions against the actual stock price movements from December 12, 2025:

We can interpret a few representative trading days and our predictions:

 

 

 

December 15, 2025

December 25, 2025

December 26, 2025

Indecision / Balance day

Pause within an uptrend?

Sellers’ close

Price moved higher intraday, but did not hold near the highs

Both buying and selling pressure were present

Neither side achieved a decisive close

Predicted price sits above the candle body, near the upper range

The model leaned toward upside continuation

Actual outcome was a balanced session rather than follow-through

 

 

Price was pushed higher intraday

Sellers closed the session lower than the open

The selling move was limited in magnitude

Predicted price lies below the candle body

The model anticipated downward pressure

Direction aligns with the close, though magnitude was overstated

 

Session closed below the open (seller close)

Price traded significantly lower intraday

The close occurred well above the session low

Indicates rejection of lower prices, but not a bullish close

Predicted price lay above the actual close

The model captured the presence of demand away from the lows

It did not capture the seller-controlled close

 

 

RANDOM FOREST ON MASAN GROUP STOCK PRICE: CONCLUSION

At first glance, the random forest model appears to perform well: predicted prices track actual prices closely, and RMSE falls below 1% once lagged price and moving-average features are introduced. However, a closer examination reveals that much of this apparent predictive power is mechanical rather than informational.

Equity prices are highly autocorrelated at short horizons, particularly for relatively low-volatility stocks such as Masan Group.  

  • As a result, introducing the prior day’s price (Lag_1) almost mechanically improves prediction accuracy, effectively reducing the problem to “tomorrow equals today plus noise.”
  • In this sense, the model’s success is not evidence of alpha generation, but rather a reflection of short-term price persistence.

Although each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day path should still be interpreted cautiously: economically rather than statistically.  Because predictions are generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than a single fixed model, the path represents a conditional evolution under expanding information rather than a fully independent set of forecasts.

INTO THE FUTURE: ITERATION 2: RETURN-BASED RANDOM FOREST (vs. Baselines)

These observations do not weaken the analysis; instead, they clarify the path toward a more rigorous modeling framework.  A more economically meaningful approach is to model price changes rather than price levels, for example by predicting log returns.

This transformation removes non-stationarity, forces the model to learn directional information, and reduces reliance on trivial persistence effects.

In the subsequent iteration, we will also introduce the trading costs, e.g., at 5bps.  This estimate highlights that even modest transaction costs can exceed the typical day-to-day predictive edge, rendering statistically accurate forecasts economically unprofitable.

In addition, any refined model must be evaluated against simple baseline alternatives such as a random walk (e.g., “tomorrow = today”), ARIMA, or moving-average extrapolation.  

  • Only if the random forest consistently outperforms these “lazy” benchmarks can it be said to add genuine predictive value.
  • Beating the baseline is, in practice, the definition of alpha.

In this sense, the current model serves an important diagnostic role: it demonstrates both the power and the limitations of machine learning applied naively to equity prices, and it motivates a more disciplined next iteration grounded in financial time-series principles.

entry.title: Re: Master Data Governance new UIBB Data Controller
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Please refer this link fo rmore insights

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/f5d3e1005efd4e86acf9a65abf428082/9202f3ee6ddc41118b325207b432a287.html?version=2023.000&q=OXK3

Collapse or Expand UIBBs

With this feature, you can choose to collapse or expand UIBBs. By using the Collapse button, you are limiting the number of UIBBs processed in a UI roundtrip, which improves performance.

Assignment of Data Controller

With this feature, all authorization checks that might impact the maintenance of business partners having data controllers are considered. You can maintain the Data Controller not Required (BUT000-DC_NOT_REQ) attribute for organizations with the new attribute, DC_NOT_RQ for entity type BP_CENTRL. Table BUT_DC_LINK is reflected in the BP data model as entity type DC_LINK with new UIBB Data Controllers. The list of data controllers is visible in the single object maintenance UIs. It remains read-only and cannot be used for manual data maintenance. The implicit assignment of data controllers is executed as part of the activation of CR.

Comments for Address (ADRCT) and Communication Data (ADRT)

You can add and maintain comments for addresses in the Comments field in the Addresses UIBB. The ADRCT table is reflected in the BP data model in entity types AD_POSTAL/ADT_POSTL and shown in the new column Comments in the UIBB Addresses. The language-dependent comments can be shown in the UIBB Comments by choosing the Detail button.

Comments for international versions of addresses are shown in the UIBB International Versions by choosing the Detail button.

The ADRT table is reflected in the BP data model in multiple entity types and shown in the new column Comments in relevant communication UIBBs. The language-dependent comments can be shown in the UIBB Comments by choosing the Comment button.

Shareholder Relationships (BUT053)

With this feature, you can maintain shareholder relationships and their corresponding company interest attributes. The BUT053 table is reflected in the BP data model as entity type BP_SHREL/TD_BPSH with the new UIBB Shareholder Relationships.

 

thanks & regards,

Balakrishna vegi

entry.title: Re: No billing documents were generated. Please see log....
entry.content:
Hi! It looks like the Exception 7 in function module VIEW_KUAG2 is the real issue here . This usually happens because the system can't find the Sales Area data for internal customer 0000030004 in the supplying company's records.

Expand the error log

Could you please click the "+" sign next to the error in your screenshot? Expanding that tree will reveal the specific sub-messages, which usually point directly to the missing field or segment that is blocking the billing document.

Recommended checks

  • Master Data: Use transaction BP to verify that customer 0000030004 is fully extended to the Sales Organization and Distribution Channel of the supplying company .
  • STO Configuration: Confirm that this specific internal customer is correctly assigned to the supplying plant within your intercompany purchasing settings .
  • Partner Functions: Ensure that the Sold-to and Payer functions are correctly maintained for the relevant sales area.

Helpful SAP Notes

  • SAP Note 207021: Covers errors related to reading customer master data.
  • SAP Note 301254: Specifically addresses the "No billing documents were generated" error.
  • SAP Note 80233: A comprehensive guide for troubleshooting Intercompany STO and billing setups .

entry.title: Re: Bapi for tcode : /SAPPCE/DPCK01
entry.content:
There is no standard BAPI (Business Object Repository) specifically named for transaction /SAPPCE/DPCK01. To automate this transaction's logic for Credit-Side Down Payment Chains, you must use internal function modules within the /SAPPCE/ namespace.

Key Function Modules

  • /SAPPCE/DPC_MASTER_MAINTAIN: Used for creating or updating the master data of the Down Payment Chain (DPC).
  • /SAPPCE/DPC_POSTING_CREATE: Used for generating transactional postings like partial invoices or final payments within the chain.
  • /SAPPCE/DPC_DPCHAIN_STATUS: Retrieves current balances and retention amounts for a specific chain.

Technical Reference Table

Object Type Technical Name Purpose

Header Table/SAPPCE/TDPC01Stores DPC numbers, company codes, and vendor data.
Items Table/SAPPCE/TDPC19Contains individual transaction records for each chain.
BAdI/SAPPCE/DPC_POSTINGUsed for custom logic during the posting process.

entry.title: Re: Is there any Standard Purchase Requisition uploader i...
entry.content:
In Cloud Public Edition, there is no generic "mass upload" Fiori app for standard Purchase Requisitions. However, you can achieve this through specific scenarios or APIs.

Standard Upload Methods

The availability of a standard uploader depends on your specific license and functional scope:

  • Central Procurement: The app Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally allows for mass creation and updates using an Excel-based "Offline Mode". Check Purchase Requisition Item | SAP Help Portal
  • Migration Cockpit: For bulk creation during implementation or data cleanup, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit provides a dedicated migration object for Purchase Requisitions. Check 3350690 - Create Purchase Requisition and Purchase Order via template | SAP Knowledge Base Article

Recommended APIs for Customization

To develop a custom Excel uploader while adhering to Clean Core principles, use the following released APIs:

API Technical NameName Description
API_PURCHASEREQUISITION_2OData V4Recommended for side-by-side extensions (BTP) or external integrations.
I_PurchaseRequisitionTPABAP RAPReleased Business Object for Developer Extensibility (on-stack) using ABAP RAP.
PurchaseRequest_InSOAPSuitable for asynchronous, message-based integrations from third-party systems.

For a modern approach, you can utilize SAP Build Process Automation to read an Excel file and trigger the OData V4 API without writing extensive custom code.

entry.title: Re: Pricing procedure in Purchase Contracts
entry.content:
As per standard behaviour, in Purchase Contracts, the unit price of the material is determined primarily by the gross price condition (PB00/PBXX or custom ZB00). Supplementary conditions (discounts, surcharges, freight, etc.) maintained in the calculation schema (RM0002 or custom ZM0002) do not change the base unit price of the material. Instead, they are applied as additional values during price determination in follow-on documents (RFQs, Purchase Orders, etc.). This means, it is expected system behavior that supplementary conditions do not directly alter the contract’s item-level unit price. They are considered only when the contract is referenced in a PO or RFQ.

Why Supplementary Conditions don’t impact Unit Price is because of the following:

Contract pricing logic:
Contracts store the agreed gross price per material. Supplementary conditions are stored but not rolled into the displayed “unit price.”

Calculation schema design:
The schema RM0002 (or your ZM0002) applies supplementary conditions in pricing simulations, but the contract document itself shows only the gross/base condition as the unit price.

System consistency:
SAP keeps the contract unit price stable to avoid confusion, while supplementary conditions flow into transactional documents where actual net price is calculated.

So in short, if your business requirement is to see them reflected in the contract’s unit price, you must customize the pricing procedure or write a routine to include them.

entry.title: Re: Bill of services from Projects-CJ20N.
entry.content:
Instead of treating trucks as externally procured services, you can model them as internal resources within Project System and integrate with Controlling.

How it works:

Define Activity Types in CO
Create activity types for truck usage (e.g., “Truck Hours”). Assign cost centers representing the fleet or vehicle groups. Maintain planned/actual rates (cost per hour).

Use Internal Activities in PS Network/Project
Assign internal activities to the project network or WBS elements. Capture actual hours worked by each truck against the project. Hours can be entered manually or via CATS (Cross‑Application Time Sheet).

Settlement & Billing
Actual truck hours posted as activity allocations flow into PS. Resource‑related billing can then pick up these internal activity postings and generate customer invoices. This way, billing is based on internal service consumption rather than external procurement.

Advantages of this approach are

  • Directly maps truck usage as internal effort rather than external services.
  • Granular tracking by vehicle number if you set up cost centers or statistical orders per truck.
  • Weekly/monthly reporting possible via PS/CO reports (hours, costs, utilization).
  • Billing flexibility: You can bill based on hours, rates, or aggregated values.

entry.title: BehaviorInvocationException: Too few values in second queue in function useOneAsMany
entry.content:
Problem Statement

In SAP CPI Message Mapping, I faced a OneAsMany violation due to mismatched occurrences between two source fields:

  • Company Code → Occurrence = 1

  • PRODUCTTAXITEM → Occurrence = 2
    So basically, due to difference in context change, I was not able to use it in value mapping where the target field occurrence is also 2 times, due to this if i use it without OneasMany, it is throwing error : target field require value for it.

This resulted in the following OneAsMany rules being violated:

Rule 1: Input 1 should not contain repeating values in the same context.

Business requirement was to:

  • Increase the context of Company Code

  • Match it with the number of PRODUCTTAXITEM occurrences

  • Repeat only the first Company Code value for all PRODUCTTAXITEM contexts.

    Groovy code used is as follows:

    import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

    // Function name must match the name used in Message Mapping UI
    def void replicateCompanyCode(
    String[] companyCode,
    String[] productTaxItem,
    Output companyCodeOut,
    MappingContext context) {

    // Guard checks
    if (companyCode == null || companyCode.length == 0 ||
    productTaxItem == null || productTaxItem.length == 0) {
    companyCodeOut.addSuppress()
    return
    }

    // Take only the first Company Code
    String firstCompanyCode = companyCode[0]

    // Create context based on PRODUCTTAXITEM count
    for (int i = 0; i < productTaxItem.length; i++) {
    companyCodeOut.addValue(firstCompanyCode)
    companyCodeOut.addContextChange()
    }
    }

    Unit test :

entry.title: A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
entry.content:
A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
CPI also creates context changes automatically when parallel queues advance differently.

What is really happening in your case

You have THREE relevant queues aligned in mapping:

  1. productTaxItem

  2. some other node (likely RECORDTYPE / TaxCode / something parallel)

  3. companyCodeOut (your UDF output)

Your UDF only controls companyCodeOut,
but CPI aligns all queues together.

Notice:

  • companyCodeOut value is SAME (BB01)

  • But another queue changes context (B2 → 22)

CPI inserts an implicit context change to stay aligned with the other node.

So:

  • Context 2 → created by your UDF

  • Context 3 → created automatically by CPI due to parallel node context shift

That’s why they appear together.

entry.title: How to Create a ServiceNow Incident via REST API Using ABAP (OAuth 2.0)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • ServiceNow instance access with API credentials (Client ID, Client Secret)
  • SAP NetWeaver with HTTP Client (CL_HTTP_CLIENT) and JSON support (/UI2/CL_JSON)

Step 1: Obtain OAuth2 Token from ServiceNow

First, you need to POST your client credentials to ServiceNow’s /oauth_token endpoint to get a bearer token. This token authorizes subsequent API calls.

ABAP Code:

FORM get_servicenow_token USING iv_token_url TYPE string
                              iv_client_id TYPE string
                              iv_client_secret TYPE string
                         CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
                                  cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, the access_token can now be used as a Bearer token.

Step 2: Build the JSON Payload

Create a JSON structure that describes the incident.

ABAP Code:

lv_json_body =
'{' &&
'"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
'"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
'"category":"Data",' &&
'"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
'"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"impact":"2",' &&
'"urgency":"2"' &&
'}'.

Step 3: Create the Incident via POST API

Now, make a POST request to the ServiceNow incident table, including your access token for authorization.

ABAP Code:

FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, cv_result will contain the incident response from ServiceNow.

Step 4: Combine the Steps in Your Report

Your main program calls these subroutines in sequence.

Example Main Logic:

* Get the access token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token
               USING lv_token_url
                     lv_client_id
                     lv_client_secret
               CHANGING ls_token
                     lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Create the incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident
                    USING lv_post_url
                          ls_token-access_token
                          lv_json_body
                   CHANGING lv_result
                            lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.

Final Notes

  • Security: Never hardcode sensitive data in productive programs—use secure storage.
  • Error Handling: Always add robust error handling and log failures for troubleshooting.
  • Data Mapping: Adjust JSON fields based on ServiceNow table and your organization’s requirements.

Conclusion

Integrating SAP and ServiceNow allows you to automatically manage ITSM incidents directly from SAP ABAP.  The above example demonstrates OAuth token retrieval and incident creation using ABAP.  Adapt and build on this foundation to suit your business requirements.

Happy Integrating! Let me know in the comments if you have any questions or need clarification on any step.

 

Complete ABAP CODE:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSNOW
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Utility: ServiceNow Incident API Integration
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

REPORT zsnow.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token,
         access_token TYPE string,
         scope        TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
       END OF ty_token.

DATA: lv_token_url     TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/oauth_token',
      lv_client_id     TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-id...',
      lv_client_secret TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-secret...',
      lv_post_url      TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/api/now/table/incident',
      lv_json_body     TYPE string,
      ls_token         TYPE ty_token,
      lv_err           TYPE string,
      lv_result        TYPE string.

* Prepare JSON Body

lv_json_body = '{' &&
               '"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
               '"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
               '"category":"Data",' &&
               '"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
               '"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"impact":"2",' &&
               '"urgency":"2"' &&
               '}'.

* Step 1: Get the Token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token USING lv_token_url
                                   lv_client_id
                                   lv_client_secret
                          CHANGING ls_token
                                   lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Step 2: Create Incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident USING lv_post_url
                                         ls_token-access_token
                                         lv_json_body
                                CHANGING lv_result
                                         lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.



*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Get OAuth Token from ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM get_servicenow_token
  USING    iv_token_url TYPE string
           iv_client_id TYPE string
           iv_client_secret TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " get_servicenow_token

*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Create an Incident in ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " create_servicenow_incident

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB Material Master Consumption Question in SAP P...
entry.content:
Hello @Ashley_Hung

Thanks for your question. The numbers in the Consumption tab are only updated when you post goods issues with movement types that are configured to update “consumption” and when the material has a Forecast view with a period indicator. If your transactions are receipts or issues with movement types that don’t update consumption, or if the Forecast view was created after the postings, the tab will stay at zero.

Common reasons why you see zeros:

1.The postings are not “consumption” postings.Purchase receipts (101), stock transfers (301/311), customer deliveries (601) and many other movement types do not update material master consumption in standard.Typical movement types that DO update consumption in standard are withdrawals such as 201/202 (to cost center), 261/262 (to production order), 281/282 (to project/WBS), 551/552 (scrapping), etc.

2.Forecast view was added after the transactions.MVER is only updated from the moment the Forecast view and period indicator exist. Past postings are not retroactively written to consumption.

3.You are looking at the wrong plant or period.Consumption is plant-specific and period-based. If reversals were posted in the same period, net consumption can be zero.

4.Movement type configuration does not update consumption.If your process uses a custom movement type or a variant whose “Update Consumption in Material Master” flag is off, consumption will not be updated.

Be aware: there is no standard job in S/4HANA Cloud to backfill historical consumption into the material master. If you need history for forecasting, use analytics based on material documents rather than relying on the Consumption tab.

Hope this can help.

Best Regards

Dave

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB PIR Update in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @Ashley_Hung ,

Thanks for your question.

That is standard system behavior. The “Update Purchasing Info Record” indicator on a supplier quotation is designed to immediately write the quoted price (including validity dates and conditions) into the purchasing info record as soon as the quotation is saved/posted in S/4HANA, independent of whether you have awarded that quotation. The award decision is a separate business step (used to drive follow-on PO creation and internal status), but it is not a technical prerequisite for PIR updates.

Why SAP does it this way

  • The PIR is the central source of supply/price for future POs and price determination. SAP’s default logic keeps it current with the latest valid quotation so buyers always see the newest price/validity when creating POs, contracts, etc.
  • The award is a purchaser decision step; it does not change the fact that a vendor has provided a valid price and validity period. SAP separates “information maintenance” (PIR) from “sourcing decision” (award/accept).

What actually triggers the update

  • When you save/post the supplier quotation and the item has “Update Info Record” selected, S/4HANA writes the price and validity to the PIR right then.
  • It does not wait for “Accept/Award” in the RFQ/quotation comparison step.

How to change or avoid this if you only want PIR updates after award

  • Process practice: Leave “Update Purchasing Info Record” unchecked during the RFQ/quotation stage. Only update the PIR from the follow-on PO you create for the awarded supplier (use the “Info Update” indicator on the PO item so the PIR is updated from the PO price), or update the PIR manually after award.
  • Configuration (Cloud): Set the default for quotations to “No info update.”
    • Manage Your Solution > Configure Your Solution > Defaults for Purchasing (SSCUI for default values). Set the default for “Quotation – Info Update” to no update so buyers don’t accidentally update PIRs at quote stage.
  • Governance option: If you still want to capture quote prices but prevent unintended use, you can block the PIR (Purchasing block) until the award, or ensure the quote validity dates are tight/short so they don’t affect POs before you decide.

Additional recommendations

  • Consider storing negotiated prices in contracts/outline agreements for the awarded supplier rather than relying solely on PIRs. Contracts give better control over validity and adoption.
  • If multiple vendor quotes exist, be mindful that the last quotation that updates the PIR will overwrite previous prices. Use validity dates or a block to avoid unintended adoption.

Hope this can help.

Best Regards

Dave

entry.title: Program Settings: Apply Gates and Accelerators
entry.content:
Hi Everyone, can someone give a practical example (business reason) for what goal gates and accelerators are used and how they can be included in a business case?  

And what is the difference between the Gates and Accelerators, and Curves?

Based on the academy, course the definition is: 

Gates and Accelerators - Overview Gates: Generally defined as some minimum performance level that must be met to receive payout on an associated goal, component (section), or the entire plan. Often tied to the incentive plan’s funding mechanism, such as revenue goals, and are used to ensure that a minimum level of funding is achieved before there is payout. Accelerators: Used to increase the incentive opportunity when certain performance criteria are met or exceeded. When a participant meets their respective accelerator performance criteria target(s), the accelerator can apply to the payout of the individual goal itself, other goals, other incentive components (sections), or the total plan payout.

Gates – Examples Gates define a minimum or threshold level of specific performance criteria that impacts payout on another goal, bonus section, or the plan itself. Gates are most often used in one of two ways. The first is a minimum level of achievement required of a specific business goal to allow for any payout against another. The second is as a threshold level that must be achieved before another goal can exceed payout beyond a certain level. Accelerators Accelerators are another feature often included in incentive plans to focus the participants’ attention on specific goals. They act to accelerate payment of a goal(s) once specific performance criteria have been met.

Example: Accelerator on Goal Payout If specific performance criteria (a business goal) are met or exceeded, the payout opportunity for other business goal(s) increases 2% for each goal that exceeds its target. The accelerator is identified as a specific goal and when this specific goal hits target, it enables the accelerator. Which is a higher payout line for other associated goals when they hit target. 

Regards, Maria

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to transport custom views in applicati...
entry.content:
Good day @Kazuhiro_F 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer to your question is, No, you cannot transport My Views of Manage Sales Orders V2 through Software Collections in public cloud.

The My Views entries like your Test view are Fiori Personalisation. They are not transported through Software Collections to Quality for Production. This is also the case even if you create a public view. The public cloud does not provide the possibility to transport request prompt and you cannot move the view to another system as a standard medium. See KBA 3329053 for more details.

An alternative you may consider if your goal is to have same filter and column layout in every system, then you should:

  • Recreate the view manually in Q and P, or
  • You make use of a key user extensibility artifact that is transportable for example App Variant or Adapt UI change, if your requirement is more than just saving a view.  Key User Extensibility and Transports provides information on Software Collections only being used for key user extensibility object and not for “My Views” end user.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: In-Depth with SAP S/4HANA 产品深度赋能系列2026 ——关注于 Cloud ERP 的产品深度赋能（合集）
entry.content:
从产品专家到产品专家，我们的目标始终如一：帮助客户和合作伙伴深度理解并高效运用 SAP Cloud ERP( S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)，推动业务创新并让云ERP投资持续产出价值。2026 年，我们将继续以系列线上研讨会的形式，带来更多面向实操的专题、示范与最佳实践分享，覆盖财务、供应链、制造、仓储与可扩展性等关键领域。

2026 年In-depth S/4HANA产品深度赋能重点系列

- Q1：服务型企业提升效率与账务透明度

主题

中国大陆本地化新负过账清账功能

专业服务模块主要流程与功能介绍

 
内容

基于中国本地化的业务需求，为了不虚增科目余额表中的借贷发生额，SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 在 2508 版本推出了负过账清账功能，本次研讨会目标在于分享该功能在各个财务流程中的应用场景。

40分钟讲师分享 + 10分钟Q&A

 
时间2026年1月8日 10:00 AM 2026年1月15日 10:00 AM
目标对象ERP 公有云客户与伙伴ERP 公有云客户与伙伴
讲师SAP 产品团队专家SAP 产品团队专家
注册注册链接注册链接
资料获取（会后）
  • 客户通道
  • 伙伴通道
  • 客户通道
  • 伙伴通道

entry.title: SAP’s Engagement in the Eclipse IDE Working Group
entry.content:
Since 2021, SAP has been a founding member of the Eclipse IDE Working Group. It was established to ensure the long-term sustainability, integrity, and evolution of Eclipse IDE products. SAP's ABAP Development Tools (ADT) are powered by the robust Eclipse platform, allowing us to leverage its extensive capabilities and flexibility. This strategic choice enables us to innovate rapidly and deliver high-quality solutions. By actively contributing and collaborating, we help shape the platform's future, mitigate potential risks, and guarantee the availability and continuous improvement of the tools our users rely on. This is currently driven by five employees with committer status.

In this article, we would like to reflect on how we were involved with the Eclipse community on behalf of SAP and the Eclipse IDE Working Group.

Looking Back On 2025

This year was a continuation of our collaboration with the Eclipse IDE community. Beyond code contributions, SAP actively participated in various events and initiatives to support and grow the Eclipse community. Key highlights have been:

  • Eclipse shipped four releases of the Desktop IDE and we are proud that some of SAP’s contributions are listed as new and noteworthy changes in the release notes.
  • SAP hosted Eclipse Platform RCP & IDE Open Community Meetups in Germany and India, giving developers, contributors, and enthusiasts a chance to connect. We covered a wide range of topics - from community updates and progress on modernizing the Eclipse UI Toolkit to improvements on performance, security, and user experience. The agenda also included demos from Eclipse Platform committers and SAP experts about new Java features and the IBM Semuru releases, practical Eclipse IDE tips, showcases of AI features in Eclipse-based products, and sessions on improving the contributor experience. Beyond the sessions, informal discussions sparked fresh ideas, proving that open source thrives through shared effort and engagement.
    Meetup in Germany, July 2025

    Meetup in India, September 2025

  • Regular engagement in the IDE working group lead to a very productive collaboration with different working group companies and other project committers, making it possible to contribute major changes such as UI modernizations.
  • To strengthen our commitment and contribution to the Eclipse IDE ecosystem, we upgraded our membership level from "Strategic Member" to the Platinum-level of the Eclipse Foundation’s IDE Working Group in 2025.
  • Sonja Liénard (@lienards), Head of ABAP Platform and true ABAP expert, was interviewed in SAP’s podcast "The Open Source Way", sharing insights into SAP’s history of the ABAP programming language and some open source fun facts, such as even Visual Studio Code using Eclipse for the Java language support. She goes into quite some details on how SAP leverages the Eclipse IDE to provide a comprehensive and flexible development environment for its technologies. Listen to the episode at https://podcast.opensap.info/open-source-way/2025/12/01/abap-and-eclipse/. 

With these activities we aimed to give our share to collaboration and continuous investment to ensure the sustainable evolution and long-term availability of the Eclipse IDE.

Looking Ahead to 2026

Building on this strong momentum, we are looking forward to continuing our open source journey with the community to propel Eclipse forward. In 2026, we also plan to host Open Community Meetups again, providing opportunities to exchange ideas, showcase progress, and strengthen connections across the ecosystem.

Saying Thank You

A big THANKS to all colleagues, community members, and contributors who make Eclipse what it is. Every idea, contribution, and discussion helping keep the platform thriving for years to come.

Let’s keep Eclipse thriving – together!

entry.title: Re: Data retention and RPO for S4 Hana Cloud Public Editi...
entry.content:
Good day @Cheng_Huang58 

Thank you for your question

1. Answer to your question regarding data retention:

Officially your business data stays in the productive tenant for the duration of your subscription. Should you contract come to an end, you have the possibility to export your data before your subscription ends. See GENERAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR CLOUD SERVICES for more details.

If your enquiry is about statutory retention periods, it is typically handled through Information Lifecycle Management. Here you can define retention rules and archiving behaviour.

See the following reference for more details on agreements: https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/agreements.html

2. Regarding your question on RPO;

RPO is not something you can configure in your tenant. It is predefined by SAP’s resilience and disaster recovery design for the service. See KBA 3396152 - FAQs about backup and recovery service for S/4HANA Public Cloud Customers. You can check the service availability and resilience information for your productive tenant.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Mastering SAP Enterprise Architecture : A Practical Certification Journey
entry.content:
During my 2025 year-end meetup with mentees, I was asked a lot of questions about the SAP Enterprise Architecture (EA) certification. What surprised me was that the majority of questions weren’t about the theory or technical aspects they were about how to prepare. How do you study? What resources help the most? What’s the exam actually like?

After completing the certification myself, I thought it would be helpful to share what worked for me. This blog answers some of the common questions based on my experience to help anyone preparing for the SAP EA certification.

Q1. What is the SAP EA certification?

SAP Enterprise Architecture (EA) certification is all about understanding how SAP's various solutions fit together in the bigger picture of an organization's IT landscape. It's not just about knowing the individual SAP products, it's about how they all work in harmony to drive business transformation.  More dive into topics like SAP S/4HANA, SAP’s Cloud solutions, SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP BDC and how to leverage them to build scalable, efficient and forward-thinking future ready enterprise systems.

It’s not just about mastering SAP tools but also understanding their strategic value in the context of business operations. It helps to really understand how different modules work together and more importantly, how they can drive value for our customer’s business.

Q2. Who should take SAP EA Certification?

If you’re someone who:

  • Working with SAP solutions or IT architecture, this certification will enhance your expertise.
  • Those aiming to become an Enterprise or SAP Solution Architect,it's perfect for expanding your skills in designing and managing complex systems.
  • Professionals in leadership roles(with strategic mindset)focused on business transformation or IT strategy, this will help you align technology with business needs.
  • Anyone who wants a deeper understanding of SAP's entire ecosystem, not just isolated tools, this certification connects all the dots or someone who wants to understand how SAP is used in real-world enterprise settings.

Q3. Why did I choose to pursue the SAP EA certification?

I’ve been working with SAP for several years and during that time, I realized how important it is to understand not just individual SAP solutions but how they fit together as part of an overall enterprise architecture. In my 2012 SCN Member of the Month interview, I shared how impressed I was by SAP Solutions's ability to solve real-world problems. The SAP EA certification offered me the opportunity to deepen my knowledge of how SAP's various tools and platforms work together to streamline business operations and drive innovation.

For me, it felt like a natural next step. If you're looking to take on a more strategic role in SAP projects, whether as an architect, consultant, or someone leading digital transformation initiatives, this certification provides the knowledge and credibility you need to guide organizations through complex SAP landscapes.

Q4. How did I start preparing for the SAP EA certification, and what study resources helped me the most?

My preparation for the SAP Enterprise Architect (EA) certification began with getting a clear understanding of the exam structure, scope, and core focus areas. I started by reading Preparation Guide for SAP Enterprise Architect which set the foundation for what I needed to know.
Once I had a sense of the areas to focus on, I turned to official SAP learning materials. These resources were my primary go-to:

  • Official SAP Learning Journeys: These are essential and aligned with certification expectations
    • Becoming an SAP Enterprise Architect 
    • Discovering SAP Enterprise Architecture
    • Exploring the sap enterprisearchitecture-framework foundation
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub:  This is Great for exploring “to-be” architectures in different industries.
  • Case Studies Live sessions: I participated in the case study exercises twice to practice analyzing real-world scenarios.
  • SAP EAF Press Book: More detail, even core Focused on merger/acquisition scenarios and two-tier SAP landscapes.
  • BTP Solution Architect Learning Journey:  This learning journey further strengthened my knowledge of integration patterns and platform-based architectures and  Getting certified Live sessions like BTP Solution architect and LeanIX which was extremely useful
  • I simply followed a structured learning approach as outlined in the Learning Journey, which was further emphasized by the Learning Hub coach, who also guided the case study exercises.

Real-world experience also helped a lot. Applying concepts to actual customer scenarios made the learning process practical and relevant.

A key tip:

Don’t skip visuals! Diagrams and images in the learning journeys are crucial for understanding how SAP components interact.

Q5. Did you clear the SAP EA certification on your first attempt?

No, I didn’t pass on my first try. It took me few attempts. I initially approached the SAP EA certification with a TOGAF enterprise architecture mindset.

While TOGAF provides a strong and valuable foundation, it is not sufficient on its own to clear the SAP EA certification. The exam requires a deep and practical understanding of SAP EAF, SAP-specific terminology, reference architectures, and how SAP positions enterprise architecture within real customer scenarios.

After reviewing my score reports, I focused on my weak areas and changed my approach(like deep dive even Diagrams and images in the learning journeys) With targeted prep and persistence, I eventually passed.

Q6. How did I prepare for scenario based questions in the EA certification?

To clear the EA certification, you need more than just memorizing theory. It’s about understanding how architectural choices work in real-world situations. A practical approach includes:

  • Focus on the "why," not just the "what": Understand why certain architectures or strategies are chosen for specific business needs.
  • Connect concepts to real projects: Relate what you’re learning to real scenarios, like S/4HANA migration or cloud integration. This helps you remember the ideas better.
  • Practice with scenario-based questions: Work through case studies and exercises that mirror real business problems.

Common types of practical exam questions:

  • Choosing the right architecture for a business need.
  • Identifying the best integration or deployment options.
  • Evaluating different solutions and making decisions, check the blog about Case for Central finance Services

Moreover, I trained myself to ask:

  • What is the business problem?
  • What solution fits best?
  • Why are other options wrong?

This mindset helped me eliminate wrong answers quickly and focus on the best solution, key to answering scenario-heavy questions.

Q7. Can a fresher or junior consultant do the SAP EA certification?

Yes, but with the right expectations.

For those like my mentees who are still working students:

  • The certification won’t immediately change your job title.
  • But it will set you up for future growth.
  • It helps you stand out in architecture discussions.

Think of it as an investment in your career, not a shortcut.

Q8. How Much Time is Needed to Prepare?

The goal isn’t to race through the material, it’s about truly understanding the concepts. I treated my preparation as a journey, not just an exam. . 

The real focus should be on grasping how everything fits together, not just memorizing facts. Consistency, deep understanding, and applying what you learn in real-world scenarios are the keys to success. Take your time, and the results will follow. 

Focus more on understanding than speed.

Q9. Will an Enterprise Architect job be obtained immediately after the SAP EA Certification?

While the SAP EA certification may not immediately result in an Enterprise Architect position, it is an important step toward that goal. The certification enhances understanding of SAP's solutions and how they integrate into business architecture, making candidates more competitive for future roles.

It builds credibility, strengthens architectural thinking, and opens doors to new opportunities. With the right experience and application of knowledge, this certification lays a strong foundation for career growth.

Q10. What is my final words for SAP EA certification aspirants?

Think beyond certification, use SAP EA as a tool to drive real-world impact. When you see the value we as EA bring to businesses, the certification will feel like just the beginning. 

it's truly a journey that builds you into an architect who can truly shape the future. Keep pushing, and your impact will be limitless.

entry.title: Re: #QDGG#Can we do configuration during S4 upgrading
entry.content:
Good day @ericyu 

Thank you for your question

Yes, you can do configuration on your CBC during S4 upgrading. However, there are clear restrictions on what you can move and when, mainly because your DEV, Q and P systems are on different releases. Check out these Blogs for more details: FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Understand Upgrading and Patching Processes of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

You can usually continue preparing configuration changes in CBC project for dev, do design an configuration preparation in DEV for the next release, perform regression testing and adjust configurations in upgraded Test system after you have concluded your upgrade. See Navigating Release Upgrades and Test System Upgrade for more details. Note that you may need to wait with the changes until your landscapes are aligned before you can move them forward.

 

Regarding testing and readiness activities, during you upgrade cycle, it is advisable to

  • Use the upgraded Test system first for regression testing, review changes and depreciations after the upgrade. See: Manage Changes and Deprecations After Upgrade and Upgrade Preparation for more information.

 

During your upgrade period, I advise:

  • Not to expect transports to production while releases are mismatched. See KBA 2791664 for more details.
  • Do not schedule your major configuration activation close to the production upgrade weekend. See FAQ on Upgrading SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for more insights, and
  • Do not leave CBC transports open across release boundaries. See KBA 3482742

 

This Blog: Mastering the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Release Readiness Check: What Every Customer Should Know provides some vital information.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris
