entry.title: Re: Stock Values Showing Zero Post Stock Adjustment
entry.content:
Some options to Correct the Stock Valuation

Post a Manual Accounting Adjustment (FI/MM Integration)
Use transaction MR22 (Change Material Valuation) to adjust the value of the stock to the correct amount. This ensures the inventory value reflects the actual procurement cost, even though the PO is closed. MR22 posts directly to stock accounts and offsetting accounts, aligning valuation.

Create a New PO for the Correct Material Number
Raise a new PO for the correct material/finish. Perform a Goods Receipt (GR) against this PO to bring the stock in with the correct value. Then, clear the manually adjusted stock (e.g., issue out the wrongly valued stock and receive against the PO). This way, the stock is properly linked to procurement and valuation flows correctly.

Material-to-Material Transfer (if applicable)
If the incorrect material number and the correct one are related, you can use transaction MB1B (Transfer Posting) with movement type 309 (material-to-material transfer). This moves stock from the old material number to the new one, carrying valuation. However, since the PO is closed and invoice paid, this may not fully resolve valuation unless combined with MR22.

Custom Business Rule (if frequent)
If this scenario happens often, consider defining a custom process in such a way that always raise a PO for corrected materials. Use transfer postings to align stock. Use MR22 only for exceptional cases.

The recommended approach is to execute MR22 to adjust the stock value directly, ff this is a one-off correction. If this is a recurring business process → Raise a new PO for the correct material number and align stock through GR, ensuring procurement and valuation flow correctly.

entry.title: Re: Sales order stock 140001513 000010 does not exist
entry.content:
Why system is triggering that error message is because, the system is telling you “Sales order stock … does not exist”. This happens because the sales order stock is tied to plant 11DB, but the physical stock is in plant 11DA. In SAP, sales order stock is special stock type (E), which is always linked to a specific sales order + plant combination. Since your STO is trying to issue stock from 11DA, but the sales order stock exists only in 11DB, the system cannot find the required stock.

Options to Resolve

Align Plant Assignment
Ensure the sales order is created for the same plant (11DA) where the stock physically exists. If the SO was created for 11DB, but stock is in 11DA, you need to either transfer the stock or adjust the SO plant.

Transfer Posting Between Plants
Use MB1B / MIGO with movement type 301 (plant-to-plant transfer) to move the stock from 11DA to 11DB. Once the stock is in 11DB, the PGI for the STO will work because the sales order stock exists in the correct plant.

Recreate STO with Correct Plant
If the business process requires shipping from 11DA, then the sales order should reference plant 11DA. Recreate the STO cycle with the correct plant assignment so that the sales order stock and STO plant match.

Check Special Stock Assignment
Verify in MD04 (Stock/Requirements List) whether the material is showing under sales order stock for 11DA. If not, you must either transfer or reassign the stock to the correct sales order/plant combination.

entry.title: Re: Shipment Tracking
entry.content:
You have used a tag "Cloud Transport Management" (CTM) which is a tool for managing software transports (moving configuration/code between systems). I don't think, this is related to your issue. If so, please remove this tag

To address the challenge of offline shipment tracking, I recommend leveraging SAP’s logistics capabilities to enable real‑time status updates. One option is to implement SAP Transportation Management (TM), which provides freight order management and allows the transportation team to record shipment milestones such as pickup, in transit, delayed, and delivered directly in SAP. These updates can also be automated through carrier integration, ensuring timely and accurate information flow.

Alternatively, if full TM implementation is not feasible, you can use embedded shipment documents in SAP S/4HANA. By linking shipments to STOs/POs, the transportation team can manually update status fields within SAP, giving stakeholders visibility into progress without relying on offline records.

Both approaches ensure that shipment statuses are captured centrally in SAP, improving transparency, streamlining billing and follow‑up processes, and enhancing customer satisfaction.

entry.title: Re: Extract Report for Workflow Approver
entry.content:
Hello @sans16 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud operational apps (such as Manage Purchase Order / Purchase Requisition / Service Entry sheet) do not provide approved by user filter. This functionality sits in the workflow task and not as a standard filed on the list report you can select.

So, yes, the public cloud offers your client the possibility to produce an audit list of items that are approved by a specific user and items currently waiting with a specific user by using Flexible Workflow Administration and or workflow task CDS based reporting. See Flexible Workflow Administration for more details.

Although the public cloud allows you to export results to spreadsheets from Fiori list pages/analytical queries, a single standard report for PO+PR+SES+all objects is not delivered as a one ready made app. I suggest you use:

  • Workflow instance monitoring (you can set the status, approver, date of completion, etc.) or
    • You can then export to download the generated list for any desired user.

  • You create a custom analytical query which is based on released workflow CDS views and filter by workflow scenario.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Negative stock in WM
entry.content:
Hi @LFRANCISCO ,
Negative stock in SAP WM usually happens when postings are inconsistent between MM and WM. To fix it, you’ll need to manually reconcile the WM stock by either creating a corrective transfer posting (LT10/LT01) or adjusting via inventory count (LX22/LX23), ensuring the warehouse is properly configured for the movement type.

The reason for appearing negative stock in WM is, Mismatch between MM and WM postings: Your MM reversal worked, but WM didn’t mirror it. If you have custom movement types, and the warehouse wasn’t configured for that movement, WM didn’t update. There can be incomplete transfer orders, Sometimes TOs are created but not confirmed, leaving WM stock negative. Posting sequence errors can cause WM to show stock that MM doesn’t.

To correct it the negative stock you can use any of the option mentioned below.

Option 1. Check Stock Situation
Use LX02 or LS24 to confirm the negative stock at storage bin level. Verify if there are open transfer orders (LT24) that might be stuck.

Option 2. Perform Inventory Adjustment
Run LX22 (Inventory Differences) or LX23 (Batch Differences). Post a physical inventory count to bring WM stock back to zero. This is the safest way if MM stock is already correct.

Option 3. Manual Transfer Posting
Use LT10/LT01 to move stock into the negative bin. Create a dummy positive posting in WM (without affecting MM) to offset the negative. Then clear it with a corrective transfer order.

Option 4. Reconfigure Movement Types
Ensure the custom movement type is linked to the warehouse in OMJJ/OMLW. Missing configuration is often the root cause. Once fixed, future postings won’t create negative stock.

Hope the option may help you to fix the issue.

entry.title: SAP Embodied AI – Future Driving Innovation Through Business AI, Robotics, and Humanoid Integration
entry.content:
Early results in proof-of-concept applications of SAP’s robotics initiative, Project Embodied AI, demonstrated up to 50 percent reductions in unplanned downtime, up to 25 percent improvement in productivity, and significant reductions in operational errors across manufacturing, warehouse automation, and quality inspection.

These results are among the reasons why SAP has expanded its Embodied AI ecosystem through partnerships with leading robotics companies and robotic enablement partners, as announced this week at SAP TechEd 2025. This builds on the recently announced collaboration with NEURA Robotics and NVIDIA to drive the future of physical AI.

To explore how SAP technology makes proofs of concepts possible in robotics, explore the reference architecture on the SAP Architecture Center site.

To get involved in SAP’s Embodied AI initiative, register here.

Through these strategic alliances, SAP continues to lead the evolution from traditional robotic tools to those that empower autonomous operations, informed by deep business context.

SAP embodied AI x Unitree robotic asset visual inspection


Source : TechEd 2025 - Philipp on Stage with Humanoid from Unitree

Unitree Robotics

Unitree Robotics provides advanced quadruped Go2 robots for warehouse navigation and asset inspection, plus G1 humanoids with human-like dexterity for logistics operations, alongside industrial B2 models for outdoor facility maintenance.

“SAP embodied AI agents will revolutionize enterprise autonomous operations from warehouse management to predictive maintenance across facilities,” said Wang Xingxing, CEO and founder of Unitree Robotics.

Watch Demo : Embodied AI robotics use case for asset visual inspection with Unitree Robotics

SAP and NEURA Robotics to revolutionize warehouse logistics

Humanoid robot 4NE1 was trained with Sartorius products in NEURA Robotics’ lab. 

Watch all the use cases demonstrated

Watch the video : 4NE1 Visual Inspection

Watch the video: SAP x NEURA x BITZER

Watch the video: SAP x Martur Fompak x Humanoid

Watch the Agibot x SAP EWM robotic AI solution video

Watch the Anybotics robotic AI solution video

Watch the Booster Robotics x SAP EWM robotic AI solution video

Watch the Galbot x SAP EWM robotic AI solution video

Watch the Unitree robotic asset visual inspection video

 
After watching all the above use case videos, you now have plenty to consider for transforming your business processes to run autonomously with robots, humanoid integration.

What is SAP Embodied AI?

  • Embodied AI combines artificial intelligence with a physical form — such as robots
  • Definition and key characteristics.
  • Difference between traditional AI and embodied AI.
  • Leverages SAP Joule for Integration
  • Real-world examples (e.g., humanoid robots, autonomous systems)

The Role of SAP in Embodied AI

  • SAP’s vision for AI-driven business processes.
  • Integration with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), Joule, SAP Business AI, Joule Studio & Skills, leading AI Models to train humanoid SDKs
  • How SAP solutions enable intelligent automation and human-robot collaboration.

AI x Robotics x Humanoids: The Synergy

  • How these technologies complement each other.
  • Use cases in manufacturing, logistics, customer service, and healthcare.
  • Benefits: Efficiency, scalability, and enhanced decision-making.

Business Impact and Opportunities

  • Cost optimization and productivity gains.
  • New business models enabled by humanoid interaction.
  • Competitive advantage through AI-driven innovation.

Challenges and Considerations

  • Ethical and regulatory aspects.
  • Workforce transformation and skill development.
  • Data security and integration challenges.

Future Outlook

  • Predictions for the next 2–3 years.
  • How SAP’s ecosystem will evolve with embodied AI.
  • Call to action: Why businesses should start preparing now.

entry.title: Re: SAP SD Plant Rollout – Configuration Scope & Common P...
entry.content:
When introducing a new plant, you need to ensure the following SD-relevant settings are in place:

Organizational Assignments
Assign the new plant to the correct sales organization, distribution channel, and division. Ensure the plant is linked to the company code and valuation area.

Shipping Point Determination
Define shipping points and assign them to the new plant. Configure shipping conditions, loading groups, and transportation groups.

Availability Check / ATP
Set up checking groups and rules for the new plant. Ensure material master data has proper MRP and availability settings.

Pricing Procedure Determination
Confirm that sales area + plant combinations are covered in pricing determination. Check condition records for freight, surcharges, or plant-specific pricing.

Output Management
Configure billing and delivery outputs for the new plant. Ensure forms/templates are aligned with customer requirements.

Partner Functions & Master Data
Verify customer master data includes the new plant for shipping and delivering. Update material master views (sales org, plant-specific storage, etc.).

Integration with MM/PP
Ensure procurement and production views are aligned. Stock transport orders and intercompany flows often need special attention.


Common Pitfalls During Testing / Go-Live

From rollout experience, here are the most frequent issues:

  • Incomplete Master Data: Materials missing plant-specific sales views, or customers not extended to the new plant.
  • Shipping Point Errors: Deliveries fail because shipping point determination is not correctly maintained.
  • ATP Failures: Availability check not working due to missing configuration or incorrect checking group.
  • Pricing Gaps: Condition records not maintained for the new plant, leading to zero or incorrect pricing.
  • Output Issues: Delivery/billing documents not generating outputs because output determination was not extended.
  • Cutover Data Quality: Incorrect stock balances or open orders migrated, causing reconciliation issues.
  • Intercompany Billing: If the new plant is cross-company, missing intercompany pricing and billing setup.

entry.title: Navigating consent: legal and ethical perspectives on transparency
entry.content:
Introduction

In aviation, pre-flight checklists and safety briefings are non-negotiable—a point Abhishek emphasized in his recent post on AI safety ( Engineering AI Safety part 1 and Engineering AI Safety part 2 ). For AI, the concept of “safety” extends beyond technical boundaries to include ethical and legal dimensions, and consent is a critical part of that equation. Just as pilots rely on checklists before takeoff, AI systems need transparent and robust consent mechanisms before engaging in digital interactions.

In particular, consent in AI interactions presents a growing challenge: users often engage with intelligent systems without realizing it, and when consent is requested, it is frequently vague, overly technical, or legally insufficient. This lack of clarity can lead to unintended data use, privacy risks, and erosion of trust. Consider a common use case: a customer interacting with a virtual assistant that collects behavioral data to improve service. Without clear disclaimers or meaningful consent mechanisms, the user may unknowingly agree to data processing that affects their rights. This scenario highlights the urgent need for transparent, accessible, and informed consent structures that reflect the dynamic nature of AI and empower individuals to make conscious decisions.

 

1. Safety instructions before takeoff: understanding consent, the foundation of agreement

Before any flight, it is imperative for passengers to comprehend the safety instructions, which are meticulously reiterated by flight attendants on every journey without exception. This is the basis to equip all passengers appropriately in any situation.

Similarly, consent in AI necessitates the same level of clarity and understanding before 'takeoff'—a clear explication is crucial to enable informed decision-making

Consent can be defined as "to agree to something or give your permission for something" (Oxford English Dictionary) or as "permission or agreement; the state of agreeing with someone or something." (Cambridge Dictionary). Consent often involves synonyms such as accept, approve, and go along with, but it is not just that: it is a shared decision-making process. However, the essence of consent lies not only in agreeing to something but in understanding precisely what is being accepted.

To ensure valid and informed consent, while each country has specific national regulations, there are universal requirements that must be met in all cases, including:

  • Capacity: Individuals must be of legal age and possess the mental maturity to fully understand what they are consenting to.
  • Voluntary agreement: Consent must be given freely, without any form of coercion, manipulation, or deception.
  • Clear content: The subject of consent must be clearly defined and easily understandable. This is crucial for ensuring that individuals fully grasp the nature and implications of what they are agreeing to.
  • Form: Depending on the nature of what is being consented to, specific forms or procedures may be required according to applicable laws and standards, e.g. consent provided in the written form may be required.
 

2. Flight path and destination clarity: the scope of consent, what are you agreeing to?

In aviation, it's crucial to define flight paths and destinations clearly before takeoff, ensuring a smooth and safe journey.

Consent is a fundamental element in various contexts, ranging from traditional contracts and personal data processing including cookies, to modern interactions with AI.

The evolution of AI has introduced new dynamics in the realm of consent, often involving personal data that fuels AI models, leading to complex legal landscapes and ethical dilemmas. As AI technologies become increasingly integrated into our lives, individuals may unknowingly consent to the use of their personal data, resulting in privacy breaches and potential misuse of information.

Therefore, disclaimers play a crucial role by providing the necessary information for individuals to consciously decide what they are consenting to. Without effective disclaimers, individuals risk consenting to broad or vague terms that may allow their data to be used in unintended ways. For instance, personal data could be used to train AI models for purposes not originally agreed upon, leading to ethical concerns and legal repercussions. Consequently, legal professionals must offer clear guidance on how legal notices and disclaimers must be structured and understood, ensuring they are comprehensible and that those consenting do so in a prior, free, and informed manner.

i. Aircraft documentation and permits: consent to personal data processing

Aircrafts require comprehensive documentation and necessary permits to fly, ensuring all safety and regulatory standards are met. In a similar vein, data processing demands formalized and documented consent, safeguarding compliance with legal standards and securing data integrity.

Before the rise of AI-specific regulations, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) stood as a cornerstone for data protection in the EU, offering a robust framework for consent related to personal data processing.

Under GDPR, consent is defined in Article 4 as a "freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes, signified by a statement or a clear affirmative action."

And Article 7 elaborates on the conditions under which consent is valid, highlighting the importance of clarity, documentation, and the subject's right to withdraw consent with ease.

Further insights are provided in Recital 32, which underscores the need for a clear affirmative act to establish consent, cautioning against methods like silence or pre-ticked boxes.  Recital 42 insists on intelligibility, accessibility, and fairness in consent declarations, emphasizing the necessity for the data subject to have genuine choice and awareness of processing purposes.

Details on SAP’s commitment to safeguarding data protection and privacy that goes beyond mere GDPR compliance can be found here https://www.sap.com/about/trust-center/data-privacy.html. 

ii.  Autopilot vs. Human control: consent to interact with AI

Users must know when AI is “piloting” decisions and what risks that entails.

The contemporary challenge lies in ensuring individuals understand interaction with AI. Several barriers exist to obtaining valid consent in this arena:

  • Clarity in terms: Terms and conditions must be clear, concise, and devoid of jargon. Ambiguous language can place individuals in a vulnerable spot, as most people tend to skim through agreements without thorough understanding.
  • Complexity of technology: Explaining AI technology—how data is captured and trained, the workings of algorithms for example—is inherently challenging. People interacting with AI are often not specialists and may struggle to fully comprehend the technicalities.
  • Dynamic nature of AI: AI systems, especially those with machine learning capabilities, continually evolve. Static explanations cannot capture the adaptive nature of AI technologies, which may change the scope and impact of consent over time.
  • Duration of consent: Granting indefinite consent poses issues, given AI's evolving landscape. Consent today reflects current technological conditions, which could subsequently change. While periodic consents are recommended to account for technological advancements, it is crucial to ensure that re-confirming consent is not merely a formality without substance. The reasons and changes behind each request for consent should be explained clearly and meaningfully, so users understand the value and importance of their informed consent.
  • Awareness of AI interaction: Individuals should be clearly informed when they are interacting with an AI system. Without this awareness, users might misinterpret AI-generated content as being human-driven, which could lead to misunderstandings or misplaced trust.

Challenges when using AI that users should be aware of include:  

  • AI hallucinations: AI can produce false or misleading information, known as hallucinations. Users must be made aware of this possibility, ensuring that their consent to interact with AI includes acknowledgment of these risks to avoid confusion or manipulation, they accept a need to verify the system output before further use.
  • Bias in AI: AI systems can harbor biases, impacting the neutrality and fairness of outputs. Such biases can affect humans in significant ways, altering perceptions and decisions based on skewed information.

Automated Decision-Making (ADM) and profiling: individuals have the right not to be subjected to decisions made solely by automated processes, including profiling, that have legal or similarly significant effects. Consent to interact with AI can lead to serious legal and personal consequences if it involves ADM. Users should be aware that AI systems may make decisions impacting their rights, such as credit approvals or job evaluations, without human intervention. Ensuring informed consent means clearly explaining these potential outcomes and allowing individuals to opt-out or request human oversight where possible. Each of these aspects underscores the essential role of transparency in interactions with AI systems. Transparency not only fosters trust and understanding among users but also ensures that consent is informed, relevant, and reflective of the evolving nature of technology. By prioritizing clarity, awareness, and regular updates on AI functionality and potential risks, we uphold the principle of transparency, which is crucial for ethical and effective engagement with AI technologies.

Understanding these complexities is pivotal for legal professionals guiding stakeholders through the intricacies of consent in digital and AI-driven environments.

Not only from a legal but also from an ethical perspective, the risks that AI automation and autonomy pose to individuals are important to consider: In SAP’s AI Ethics Governance process, use cases that involve automated decision making need to specifically prove that this doesn’t entail significant harm for individuals (see AI Ethics Handbook, chapter AI Ethics Assessment Process).

 

3. International frameworks: navigating the regulation of AI consent

Global aviation relies on ICAO standards to ensure safe flights across all skies—AI needs similar international frameworks to guarantee transparency and informed consent in any digital “airspace.”

In the rapidly evolving sphere of AI, numerous international regulations, recommendations, and codes of conduct are shaping the landscape of consent. This comprehensive set of guidelines aims to ensure ethical AI interaction and transparency.

Some the most notable frameworks are EU AI Act, UNESCO's Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence, EU's Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI, OECD AI Principles, Code of Conduct for AI Developers under the Hiroshima AI Process, Code of Practice for the AI Act, among others.

Summary of international requirements:

The global standards for consent in AI focus on several key principles:

  • Ensuring humans are aware they are interacting with AI systems, such as chatbots or digital assistants, by clearly stating their AI nature.
  • Providing clear and distinguishable identification of AI upon first interaction.
  • Utilizing mechanisms such as labels or disclaimers, akin to widely recognized symbols or logos.
  • Meeting accessibility requirements for vulnerable populations.
  • Aligning biometric data processing with GDPR protocols to safeguard emotions or intentions.
  • Facilitating human interaction options when essential for upholding fundamental rights, particularly in the context of ADM processes.
  • Recognizing exceptions, such as obviousness to informed users or for criminal investigations.

These international guidelines establish a cohesive ethical and transparent framework for AI consent, paving the way for responsible AI deployment and fostering trust across diverse demographics.

Transparency is a foundational principle across international AI ethics frameworks. While explicit consent is required in certain contexts, many regulations recognize that transparency obligations may be fulfilled through clear AI notices or disclosures. Guidelines from bodies such as UNESCO, the OECD, and the European Commission emphasize the importance of informing individuals when interacting with AI systems, explaining how decisions are made, and ensuring that AI processes are traceable and understandable. These measures aim to safeguard human rights and foster trust in AI technologies.

 

4. Recommendations: crafting effective disclaimers for valid consent

To achieve valid consent in AI interactions, it is crucial to address both the clarity of communication and user understanding, and therefore, it is necessary to be transparent.

Here are key recommendations to ensure that disclaimers are effective and consent is valid:

Prioritize clarity and simplicity

  • Use clear language: Employ straightforward, accessible language that avoids technical jargon. The goal is to ensure that users of all backgrounds – the average person- can easily understand the information presented.
  • Concise disclaimers: Keep disclaimers brief but comprehensive. Focus on delivering essential information that captures the nature of AI interactions and any implications they may have. A valuable initiative to consider is the proposal by the Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, which suggests that terms of service be presented in a single page, containing no more than 500 words.

Enhance transparency

  • Explain AI functionality: Clearly describe how the AI system processes data, makes decisions, and its intended use.
  • Identify AI systems: Ensure that AI systems are explicitly identified as such, confirming users are aware they are interacting with non-human technology.

Facilitate informed consent

  • Provide explanations on impact: Offer insights into how AI interactions might affect users, including potential impacts on rights or safety.
  • Accessibility features: Consider accessible formats that cater to diverse populations, ensuring that all users, including vulnerable groups, can access and understand the information provided.
  • Nudging?

Guarantee flexibility and options

  • Offer alternatives: When possible, provide options for human interaction to comply with fundamental rights and cater to user preferences.
  • Revisit consent periodically: AI technology evolves rapidly; regular reassessments of consent validity are recommended. Periodic renewal of consent ensures alignment with current technological conditions.

Address ethical standards

  • Commit to transparency: Continuously update and refine the transparency measures as outlined in international ethical guidelines to maintain trust and uphold accountability.

Implementing these recommendations helps ensure that user consent, particularly in AI interactions, is valid, informed, and ethically sound. They are also used legally and in appropriate situations, forming the basis for crafting disclaimers that are both effective in legal contexts and respectful of user rights and autonomy.

SAP employs two fundamental design patterns to uphold the transparency principle for end-users interacting with AI: (i) AI Acknowledgment at SAP, which appears when a user accesses the AI feature and typically provides information about the service, terms, and conditions:

and (ii) AI Notice at SAP, located near every AI feature output within our cloud services, usually featuring the language: “Created with AI. Verify before use.”:

Closing

Every flight ends with a safe landing and a post-flight review—AI consent should follow the same principle: conclude with clarity and prepare for the next journey.

Consent in AI is much more than a legal formality—it’s a dynamic process that requires clear communication, genuine user understanding, and ongoing transparency. As AI systems become more integrated into daily life, it’s essential that users are fully aware when they interact with AI, understand the implications of their consent, and have real options to control their data and experiences. International standards and regulations increasingly reflect these priorities, making transparency and user empowerment central to responsible AI.

In the next post, we’ll continue exploring new challenges and practical solutions around transparency in AI—stay tuned for more insights, and keep_the_blue_side_up

References / further reading

AI Transparency Blogpost Series

  • Introductory Blogpost:  Keep the blue side up: Building trust in AI through transparency (Responsible AI blogpost series) - SAP Community - Laugwitz, Bettina
  • Explainability Blogpost: Trustworthy AI: How to make artificial intelligence understandable  - SAP Community - Laugwitz, Bettina
  • Engineering AI Safety Blogpost (part 1): Engineering AI Transparency: Ideation and validation (Part 1) - SAP Community - Pant, Abhishek
  • Engineering AI Safety Blogpost (part 2):  Engineering AI Transparency: From Build to Operations (Part 2)  - SAP Community - Pant, Abhishek
